properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A rainy and windy Christmas On Christmas Eve, a strong southerly flow will bring mild temperatures, sustained winds and rain to the entire province. These conditions will spread from west to east until Christmas day. Areas north of the St. Lawrence River will receive the most significant rainfall amounts. Rainfall amounts of 20 to 60 millimetres are expected with up to 80 mm in Charlevoix. The heavy rain may cause flash floods and ponding on roads. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T08:15:28-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T16:15:28-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3583824159.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 10 to 20 cm is expected. A frontal system will stall over the region bringing periods of heavy snow tonight and Thursday. Snow will begin this evening and intensify overnight. Periods of heavy snow will continue through Thursday afternoon. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong arctic cold front worked its way across the prairies overnight. Strong northwesterly winds in its wake are combining with the freshly fallen snow to create poor visibilities in blowing snow over open areas. Winds will moderate slightly later this morning with visibilities gradually improving. ### Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall is expected today. Snow will continue today and will gradually taper to flurries from west to east on Thursday afternoon. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. Locally higher amounts near 30 cm are possible. Brisk northerly winds gusting 50 to 60 km/h early this evening and into Thursday will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. Driving conditions will deteriorate today as the snow continues. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chills near minus 45 are occurring early this morning but are expected to moderate slightly by noon. Extreme wind chills are likely to return tonight. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Risks are greater for young children, older adults, people with chronic illnesses, people working or exercising outdoors, and those without proper shelter. Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. For more information on cold and your health, visit Manitoba Health at https://www.gov.mb.ca/health/publichealth/environmentalhealth/cold.html or call Health Links - Info Santé at 204-788-8200 or toll-free at 1-888-315-9257. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T08:29:49-00:00

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain developing tonight followed by potentially heavy snow Thursday evening into Friday. Rain is forecast to begin tonight ahead of an approaching low pressure system. As the low pressure system lifts northward Thursday, the rain is forecast to transition over to snow. The snow may become mixed with ice pellets or freezing rain for a period Thursday or Thursday night. By Friday, Christmas Day, the snow may become heavy at times, resulting in hazardous travel conditions. Local blowing snow is also possible. Snowfall accumulations in the 5 to 20 cm range will be possible, with the majority of the snow falling early Friday morning, which is Christmas morning. Snowfall Warnings may be required. There remains considerable uncertainty as to the exact track of the low pressure system responsible for the rain and snow. This will ultimately affect how much snow may fall at a particular location. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T07:18:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T15:18:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0783810022.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall expected today. Snow will continue today and may mix with rain, predominantly near to the shoreline of Lake Superior before transitioning back to snow tonight. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Thursday evening. Snowfall amounts will likely be less than 10 cm near the shoreline of Lake Superior due to a mix of wet snow and rain expected there today. Driving conditions will deteriorate today as the snow continues. Motorists should consider changing travel plans accordingly. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

Area: Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall possible on Christmas Day. Rain is forecast to begin tonight ahead of an approaching low pressure system. This rain will then transition to light snow Thursday afternoon or Thursday evening. A few centimetres of snowfall accumulation will be possible by Christmas morning. Then Christmas Day, a new low pressure system is forecast to track northward towards the area, spreading heavy snow ahead of it. Snowfall accumulations in the 5 to 15 cm range will be possible, before a potential transition to ice pellets or freezing rain. Several hours of ice pellets or freezing rain may occur before the precipitation gradually tapers off Friday night. Snowfall Warnings may be required at a later time. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T07:25:27-00:00

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A significant winter storm is expected today. Snow will continue today and gradually taper to flurries from west to east on Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 25 to 35 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. Total accumulations of up to 50 cm locally are possible. Snow may mix with rain along the shoreline of Lake Superior this morning and into this afternoon as temperatures briefly rise above the freezing mark. As a result, lesser snowfall accumulations are anticipated immediately along the lake shore. Brisk northerly winds gusting 50 to 60 km/h are expected from this evening into Thursday and will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. Driving conditions will continue to deteriorate today as the snow continues. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:
Description: Significant rainfall expected Thursday into Friday morning. Rain is forecast develop over Eastern Ontario Thursday morning. This rain is then expected to continue through Thursday night. Total rainfall amounts of 30 to 50 mm are likely with this event. By Friday morning, Christmas Day, the rain is expected change to scattered flurries or periods of snow as temperatures drop to below the freezing mark. A few centimetres of snow will be possible. This rain is associated with a strong low pressure system that will approach the area from the south Thursday. There remains some uncertainty as to the exact track of this low pressure system. Areas closer to and including Central Ontario may transition to snow earlier than currently forecast, changing associated precipitation amounts. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is a possible as the frozen ground has a reduced ability to absorb rainfall. Rainfall Warnings may be required as the event draws closer. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T06:36:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T14:36:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3653529713.2020
Area: Gatineau, Belleville - Quinte West - Eastern Northumberland County, Cobourg - Colborne - Western Northumberland County, Tamworth - Sydenham - South Frontenac, Stirling - Tweed - Madoc, Kingston - Odessa - Frontenac Islands, Napanee - Consecon, Picton - Sandbanks Park, Merrickville-Wolford - Kemptville, Westport - Charleston Lake, Brockville - Prescott, Gananoque - Mallorytown, Maxville - Alexandria, Cornwall - Lancaster, Winchester - Newington, Morrisburg - Long Sault, Bancroft - Hastings Highlands - Denbigh, Kaladar - Bannockburn - Bon Echo Park, Prescott and Russell, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe, Renfrew - Arnprior - Calabogie, Smiths Falls - Perth - Eastern Lanark County, Plevna - Sharbot Lake - Western Lanark County, Ottawa North - Kanata - Orléans, Ottawa South - Richmond - Metcalfe
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potentially heavy rain followed by significant snow early Friday. Rain is forecast to begin tonight ahead of an approaching low pressure system. This rain will then continue into Thursday and become heavy at times. Total rainfall amounts of 15 to 25 mm are likely. By Thursday evening or Thursday night, the rain is expected to change over to snow after the passage of a strong cold front. Several centimetres of snowfall accumulation will be possible Thursday night through Friday morning, which is Christmas morning. Locally significant accumulations may cause hazardous driving conditions into Saturday morning. There remains considerable uncertainty as to the exact track of this low pressure system and the timing of the changeover from rain to snow. This will ultimately affect how much snow may fall at any particular location. Motorists should be prepared for deteriorating winter driving conditions in areas that receive snow from Thursday evening through Friday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T07:01:42-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T15:01:42-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3797926179.2020

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:

Snow will combine with gusty southwesterly winds to produce local areas of blowing snow tonight and Thursday morning. Snow will taper off Thursday morning. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow is expected over northern sections. Snow at times heavy will spread across areas north of Missinaibi lake today and gradually taper to flurries from west to east on Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. Locally higher amounts up to 25 cm are possible for areas closer to Kapuskasing and Hornepayne. Brisk northerly winds gusting 50 to 60 km/h are expected from this evening into Thursday and will result in localized blowing snow over exposed areas. Areas south of Missinaibi lake, which include the city of Chapleau and Sultan, will not receive as much snow. These areas may receive a few centimeters of snow this morning followed by rain showers this afternoon. Early Thursday morning, the rain showers will transition to snow and taper to flurries Thursday afternoon. A total snowfall amount of up to 5 cm is possible for these areas on Thursday. Consider post-poning non essential travel in the northern areas until conditions improve. Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T06:43:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-12-23T14:43:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3165967423.2020
Area: Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A strong arctic cold front worked its way across the prairies overnight. Strong northwesterly winds, gusting at times to 80 km/h, are occurring in its wake. These winds are combining with freshly fallen snow to create poor visibilities in blowing snow over open areas. The blizzard conditions will persist this morning but gradually improve towards midday or early this afternoon as winds moderate slightly. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to MBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #MBStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T01:59:41-00:00

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall today and tonight. Snow currently over northern Ontario will continue to spread northeastward towards James Bay today. The snow will continue tonight before gradually ending from west to east on Thursday. Total snowfall amounts of 15 to 25 cm are expected by Thursday afternoon. Locally higher amounts in excess of 30 cm will be possible. Difficult winter driving conditions are expected. Motorists should consider changing their travel plans accordingly. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Snowfall warnings are issued when significant snowfall is expected. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A period of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme wind chill values near -45 are expected to warm up later today bringing an end to the extreme cold warning. Tonight, there is a chance these extreme wind chill values will return in northeastern Saskatchewan, including Collins Bay and Southend regions. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to SKstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #SKStorm.

properties.Summary:

Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in blowing snow is expected or occurring. Strong winds, gusts to 90 km/h, will combine with the freshly fallen snow to create poor visibility in blowing snow through most of the day. These strong winds will continue into the evening hours. The visibility should improve late Wednesday evening as winds weaken. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Visibility may be significantly and suddenly reduced to near zero. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-12-24T08:14:37-00:00
